TA 8410-PAK: Power Distribution Enhancement Investment Program 
PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  is  necessary  on  the  following 
grounds: 
(i)  The Investment Program is urgently needed in Pakistan.  
(ii)  While the Government of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan has a plan to invest in 
the  program,  there  is  a  need  to  prepare  a  feasibility  study  to  process  the 
investment program and loan for Tranche 1. 
(iii)  Expertise  of  competent  international  and  national  consultants  is  needed  to 
prepare the Investment Program considering its technical complexity and scale. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $1.8 million equivalent, of which $1.5 million equivalent 
will be financed on a grant basis by  the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Technical Assistance 
Special  Fund  (TASF-V).  The  government  through  the  Pakistan  Electric  Power  Company 
(PEPCO), Islamabad Electric Supply Company (IESCO) and Lahore Electric Supply Company 
(LESCO) will provide counterpart support in the form of staff, data and information provision, 
office and communication facilities for consultants, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed 
cost estimates are in Table A4.2.

3

Source: Asian Development Bank staff estimates. 
 
D.  Consulting Services 
4.  The PPTA will employ (i) an international consulting firm for conducting the feasibility 
study,  technical,  financial  and  economic  due  diligence,  preparing  bidding  documents  and 
technical specifications; and (ii) individual experts (international and national) for assisting the 
implementing agencies in evaluating bids, capacity development, assessing utility operations 
and recommending improvements, conducting sector assessment and updating of road map, 
Individual experts will also be hired and assessing environment, social and gender impacts. The 
required services are summarized in Table A4.3. The quality- and cost-based selection method 
(80:20) will be used with full technical proposal for the recruitment of consulting firm.  
 
Table A4.3: Summary of Consulting Services Requirement  
(in person-months)

AMI = advanced metering infrastructure, pm = person-month, TL = team leader. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

4   
 
5.  Under the proposed PPTA, the consultants will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Project feasibility study for the AMI development. The study covers technical, 
economical and financial assessment of the project, and includes due diligence 
on  project  impact,  outcome,  scope,  cost,  schedule,  and  implementation 
arrangements. Preparation of the facility administration manual (FAM), Planning 
Commission (PC) 1, disbursement projections, bidding documents, procurement 
plan  and  technical  specifications.  Conducting  of  financial  management 
assessment. [a consulting firm] 
(ii)  Capacity  Building.  Conduct  needs  assessment.  Prepare  training  modules, 
material and program. Organize and conduct trainings. Organize road shows for 
the  project.  The  training  should  aims  at  (i)  gaining  knowledge  of  advanced 
metering  infrastructure  (AMI)  functions  from  international  best  practices  and 
experiences; and (ii) learning international best practices to manage and operate 
the distribution system effectively and reduce losses.[individual consultant] 
(iii)  Support  for  project  preparation.  The  consultants  will  conduct  sector 
assessment and prepare sector road map, followed by assessment of utility 
operations with recommendations for improvement. Experts will also be required 
to assess environmental, social and gender impacts, and develop frameworks. 
The procurement expert will assist the implementing agencies in evaluating the 
bids  and  recommending  award  of  contract  to  the  least  cost  substantially 
responsive bidder. [individual consultants] 
   
A.  Implementation Arrangements 
6.  PEPCO  will  be  the  executing  agency;  LESCO  and  IESCO  will  be  the  respective 
implementing  agencies  for  the  PPTA.  The  project  management  units  (PMUs)  already 
established under the existing MFF, one in each distribution company (DISCO) and one in 
PEPCO, will act as the PPTA coordinating units. PEPCO and the DISCOs will continue to 
allocate sufficient resources as required for the preparatory works. The PMUs will work closely 
with the PPTA consultants. Disbursements under the PPTA will be done in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Handbook (May 2010, as amended). PPTA may also cover travel 
and related costs of ADB PPTA administering staff in order to participate in the road shows to 
be conducted under the PPTA. 
 
7.  The proposed PPTA processing and implementation schedule is in Table A4.4.  
 
Table A4.4: Technical Assistance Processing and Implementation Schedule 
Expected 
Major Milestones  Completion Date 
May 2013 
-  Reconnaissance mission 
July 2013 
-  PPTA Approval

-  Individual consultant recruitment  
December 2013 
-  Consulting firm recruitment 
December 2014 
-  Physical completion 
June 2015 
-  Financial closure 
 
PPTA = project preparatory technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank
